results.title: The New 2024 Ford F-150
results.content: Customers have access to more available driver assist technology across all F-150 models and trim levels, including in-demand features like Ford BlueCruise and a 360-degree camera. Customers of the 2024 F-150 will experience Ford BlueCruise 1.2, which allows for new capabilities like Lane Change Assist – which can perform a hands-free lane change at the tap of the turn signal – and In-Lane Repositioning to help adjust the vehicle’s position by subtly shifting away from vehicles in adjacent lanes, such as large semi-trucks, for instance. The Ford F -150® Tremor® design is new for 2024 and engineered for customers seeking a purpose-built off-roading vehicle19 that maintains all the truck functionality of F-150.

results.title: Ford F-150 vs. Chevy Silverado 1500 vs. Ram 1500 - MotorTrend
results.content: For the 2025 Ram 1500, the best fuel economy offered comes from the Tradesman HFE (high fuel efficiency) model fit with the 3.6-liter V-6 engine. Chevy is the last manufacturer to offer a diesel engine in its light-duty pickups, and it is paying dividends in the area of fuel economy with two-wheel-drive Silverado fitted with the 3.0-liter Duramax offering as high as 29 mpg on the highway. Today, the highest available tow rating for a half-ton is 13,500 pounds, with an EcoBoost-powered Ford F-150 Super Cab. Chevy follows with a maximum of 13,300 pounds with a 3.0-liter Duramax-powered two-wheel-drive crew cab. Chevy’s Silverado 1500 regular cab offers a maximum payload rating of 2,260 pounds when fitted with a 2.7-liter TurboMax engine and either bed.

Activision Blizzard Inks $54M Deal In Calif. By Andrew Karpan
A federal judge in California has decided to tear up some of the allegations in VLSI's $900 million lawsuit against Intel, deciding in advance of a trial next year that there isn't any way Intel's microchips in the U.S. do what's described in one of the licensing company's patents, and that a second patent is indefinite.
 By Craig Clough
A New York judge on Friday tossed a lawsuit brought by Chubb Insurance against the Archdiocese of New York over a slew of sex abuse complaints the church is facing, saying that under the "plain language" of the policies the church held, it is "obvious" they cover the lawsuits.
 By Hailey Konnath
The Fifth Circuit on Friday vacated the Federal Trade Commission's order blocking Illumina's $8 billion reacquisition of cancer-detection company Grail, agreeing with the commission that the combination is "likely to substantially lessen competition," but finding that the FTC used the wrong legal standard in part of its analysis.
 By Ivan Moreno
The U.S. Supreme Court decided the First Amendment does not shield a poop-themed dog toy from infringement claims in a suit over a parody of Jack Daniel's famous whiskey bottles, and the justices concluded federal trademark law does not extend to conduct in other countries.
